newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine hryvnia weakness temporary - central bank.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine hryvnia weakness temporary - central bank.

text.p: Ukraine's hryvnia currency fell to 1.8150 to the U.S. dollar on Tuesday from near-record highs last week of 1.765, as Ukrainian banks held on to dollars, seeking higher levels at which to sell, a central bank official said.
"It's part of the game, and the drop will not continue," said Mykola Melnychuk, chief of hard currency reserves. "I wouldn't say the banks have a lot of hryvnia at the moment."
The hryvnia began its drop on Monday, hitting 1.791 to the dollar from 1.765 at the end of last week.
Its initial climb to the highs was attributed by economists to increased buying on the Treasury bill market and an influx of foreign donor money into Ukraine.
"The market is very sensitive right now. If an investor comes in and spends $10 or $20 million, then we'll see the trend reverse itself," Melnychuk said.
He said the change was not worrying the bank, which liked to see the hryvnia trading between 1.76 and 1.90 to the dollar.
"This really is not a big difference," he said. "I remember earlier when the currency changed by 20 percent, not one percent," he said.

The hryvnia was introduced to replace the interim karbovanets currency, which started at about 40 "coupons" to the dollar after independence in 1991 and reached 200,000 to the dollar when it was withdrawn last September.
